Issues.Title: Improve Observables Testing documentation
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description of the problem

Observables are a huge part of Angular.

Currently, the testing docs have examples on how to test Observable related code scattered across docs and we don't have a dedicated place to learn about Observable testing. 

A lot of examples are scattered around the docs and suggest either testing observables by subscribing (without unsubscribing BTW which is another issue), or [showing how to test using marble tests](https://angular.io/guide/testing-components-scenarios), (and doing it only in the "components section" although it's not limited only to components).
And by that it seems like we're jumping from the "easiest thing possible" straight to "having to know hot, cold, TestScheduler and look at all these signs!" type of tests (marble testing).

When there is a much simpler way to test Observables.
It pretty new but very effective (according to people who used it in real life) and it's called: 

### [`observer-spy`](https://github.com/hirezio/observer-spy) 

I created it a few months ago with the aim of reducing complexity when it comes to testing observables.

So although I'm biased, I waited a few months to see whether this open source library actually provide value to devs other than my clients before I thought about suggesting to add it to the docs.

So far it seems that it makes people lives' easier.

For example, here are some of the responses I got since it got published - 

---

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1430726/95263162-0cbe8200-0836-11eb-9d78-45a7e64c38f7.png)

---

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1430726/95263462-7dfe3500-0836-11eb-8aca-0d9283b2d66b.png)

---

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1430726/95263672-d1708300-0836-11eb-8fb2-2906105e18f7.png)

---

Observer spies are much less complicated than marble testing and don't require testing implementation details like knowing exactly how many frames passed between values (which normally you only care about the values and their order, rather than the time between them). 

I believe marble testing should be the last topic we cover on Observable Testing to reduce the friction newcomers have when trying to learn Angular + testing, and to supply them with the simplest tools first before jumping into the more complicated ones üòÖ 

### Proposed Solution - a Dedicated "Observables Testing" Document

Because Observables are a cross cutting topic which can be found in all Angular types (services, components, etc), I believe it should have it's own document called "Observables Testing".

In there we should start by showing the simplest way (subscribing to get a value), then showing how to use observer-spies and with `subscribeSpyTo` and `autoUnsubscribe` (not to leave any leaks), the move to show how to auto-spy on dependencies which return observables and lastly - show how to test using marble tests. 

#### The proposed table of contents:

1. An Observable Under Test - the easiest way
2. Testing multiple values - using observer spies
3. Faking dependencies with Observable returning methods
4. Marble Tests

I believe this would make the whole notion of Observable testing much easier to digest and get easy wins in both Angular and also NgRx code (like testing effects) and will help lower the entry barrier for testing Observable.  

Let me know what you think. If we move forward, I could create a draft of the content and work with your documentation team to include it on Angular.io.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Improve Observables Testing documentation" (#39144)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler-cli): wrap RHS of property write in parens
Issues.Body:
The right needs to be wrapped in parens or we cannot accurately match its
span to just the RHS. For example, the span in `e = $event /*0,10*/` is ambiguous.
It could refer to either the whole binary expression or just the RHS.
We should instead generate `e = ($event /*0,10*/)` so we know the span 0,10 matches RHS.
This is specifically needed for the TemplateTypeChecker/Language Service
when mapping template positions to items in the TCB.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(compiler-cli): wrap RHS of property write in parens" (#39143)

Issues.Title: Do something with `yarn add` removing __ivy_ngcc__ folders
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package

Probably @angular/compiler

### Description

When `ngcc` precompiles npm packages in `node_modules`, it puts compilation results into the `__ivy_ngcc__` folder next to package contents.

When `yarn add` is run, it cleans npm packages in `node_modules` of files not belonging to the package, removing `__ivy_ngcc__` folders as well.

So, when using `yarn`, adding a package results in compilation of all `node_modules`, which is awfully annoying, especially in real-world Angular projects where `ngcc` takes minutes.

Demo repo: https://github.com/earshinov/angular-yarn-sample. Repro steps are in the README.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would prefer if `ngcc` put its compilation sources somewhere outside of `node_modules` or, alternatively, into `node_modules/.cache` which yarn seems to recognize as a cache folder and leave intact.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Yarn could have an option to leave files in node_modules intact, but I guess it would run counter its inclination to keep content inside `node_modules` consistent for all users.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Do something with `yarn add` removing __ivy_ngcc__ folders" (#39140)

Issues.Title: Export RadioControlRegistry to be able to use it for custom implementations of ControlValueAccessor
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for @angular/forms.


### Description
I am trying to implement `ControlValueAccessor` for a custom radio component, but the problem is that for radio buttons we need to deselect/select other radios of the same group when one is selected as it is done in https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/c0523fc3b45cdb5ba52109f7ae0e4dab555b7d72/packages/forms/src/directives/radio_control_value_accessor.ts using `RadioControlRegistry`, except that this registry is not exported for external use.


### Describe the solution you'd like
Export `RadioControlRegistry` to be able to use it when implementing `ControlValueAccessor` without needing to create a new one internally in the project where it's being implemented.

I can propose a PR if you consider this as needed.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
N/A
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Export RadioControlRegistry to be able to use it for custom implementations of ControlValueAccessor" (#39136)

Issues.Title: feat(language-service): merge compiler options, watch extended configs
Issues.Body:
Currently the language service watches only the root config file of a
configured project for changes. However, since the Angular CLI merges
compiler options across all referenced config files, the Angular LS
should do the same, and watch for changes in any relevant config file.

This commit does the following:
   - Defer compiler option parsing to
     `perform_compile.readConfiguration`, which already merges compiler
     options across extended config files. Furthermore, return all
     extended config files from `readConfiguration`.
   - Attach file watchers to the project root config file, and all known
     extended config files as determined by `readConfiguration`. On a
     change to any config file, refresh the compiler options known by
     the Angular LS, and attach file watchers for any newly-extended
     config files.
     - Also: properly clean up file watchers, closing them when a file
       is deleted.

To test these changes, the mock server host is extended to support a
mock filesystem. This is needed because ngtsc reads files from a file
system interface, which the mock service does not provide. Furthermore,
methods on the mock filesystem defer to the mock host, so the host was
chosen to implement a filesystem rather than the service doing so.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(language-service): merge compiler options, watch extended configs" (#39134)

Issues.Title: Required validator does not work with number
Issues.Body:
Re-opened a bug issue that wasn't resolved, but closed due to inactivity.

https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/6932

> The required validator does not work with a input whose type is number :
> <input type="number" ngControl="weight" />
> 
> this.form = fb.group({
>   weight: ["", Validators.required]
> });
> When the input is empty, no error appear.
> 
> The reason is that the NumberValueAccessor selector match the input, and set the value of the Control to a number. If the entered string of the input does not match a number, the value is NaN. This is the case for the empty string.
> But the required validator return a error only if the control value is blank (null or undefined) or is a empty string. This is not the case of any of these two conditions because the NumberValueAccessor set the value to the NaN number.
> 
> The required validator can not really verify the NaN value because it can appear for empty string, but also for string that are not a number (like 'aaa'). The problem is that the validator can not retrieve the entered string from the control variable.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Required validator does not work with number" (#39132)

# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package `@angular/common/http` ### Is this a regression? No, it seems an issue by design. Some thoughts about this are shared in #36974 ### Description Providing `HTTP_INTERCEPTOR` seems tricky. **What we expect**: Inherit the interceptors from the root module if you haven't configured anything in the child module. **What we get**: a dummy `HttpXsrfInterceptor` injected in the child modules, overriding the defined ones. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://matheo.github.io/ng-providers/ Angular 9: https://github.com/matheo/ng-providers/tree/819c17bb2587e0192c6d30f49b32844e6c39c3ca Angular 10: https://github.com/matheo/ng-providers/tree/68746d996916fea5c408071848ed44eb7c26af9a ## üî• Exception or Error It causes problems on code relying on Custom Interceptors, and it should not pollute the child module interceptors right? ## üåç Your Environment

Here is ID from $localize: 4998556035340110929 and here is from template 47c477a6e7959ffde7a0ab247ec1c88468d5e101. Looks like ones from templates is hexadecimal where from $localize are numbers only. Issues.Title: feat(compiler): support tagged template literals in code generator
Issues.Body:
Add a TaggedTemplateExpr to represent tagged template literals in
Angular's syntax tree (more specifically Expression in output_ast.ts).
Also update classes that implement ExpressionVisitor to add support for
tagged template literals in different contexts, such as JIT compilation
and conversion to JS.

Partial support for tagged template literals had already been
implemented to support the $localize tag used by Angular's i18n
framework. Where applicable, this code was refactored to support
arbitrary tags, although completely replacing the i18n-specific support
for the $localize tag with the new generic support for tagged template
literals may not be completely trivial, and is left as future work.

Issues.Title: Angular 7 libraries do not support APP_INITIALIZER unless the library is in the same application
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/core ### Is this a regression? Unknown ### Description Angular app initializer factory functions only run when the library is contained in the same application directory as the client application. Eg an angular application with a projects folder can be used to build the project and import the angular library. This will cause the factory function to run. generating a new app and using npm link to also make use of that library will not trigger the factory function to run. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Due to the nature of npm link used as part of reproduction stackbitz wouldnt help so I have created a repository: https://github.com/CraigComeOnThisNameCantBeTaken/angular_init_bug_reproduce Download and build the library found in AppInitError > navigate to the resulting dist folder> npm link serve AppInitError > observe the console.log running navigate to usesNpmLink > npm link under-test serve usesNpmLink > observe that the console.log does NOT run ## üî• Exception or Error Silent issue ## üåç Your Environment Windows 10 **Angular Version:**

OS: win32 x64

Issues.Title: Building an application automatically watch for libraries changes
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [x] build
- [x] serve
### Description
Whe working in an Angular workspace,
you have to run `ng build [lib] --watch` on all libraries and then `ng build [app] --watch`
to detect the changes and rebuild the application with the latest libraries changes.

### Describe the solution you'd like
‚Ä¢ A flag (`--watchLibraries=opts`?) to automatically build & watch libraries when running `ng build [app] --watch`
or
‚Ä¢ An option in angular.json to make it dependent on the configuration.

`opts=true|false|noFirstBuild`:
true/false: activate / deactivate the functionnality.
noFirstBuild: to prevent having to compile lots of libraries each time you run the command, you can choose to only build them if they changed after the application has been built.

How to detect the libraries:
Using `angular.json#projects.[project].projectType` (= library)

### Describe alternatives you've considered
npm scripts, but each time you add a library you need to add it in the scripts.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Building an application automatically watch for libraries changes" (#18985)

Issues.Title: Inline SourceMap Option
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

Related issue: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/13543

### Command 

- [X] build
- [X] serve

### Description

Please consider a inline source map option again. It's just one more option. It's easy to implement in the Angular webpack config. It's just one attribute. See [docs](https://angular.io/cli/build).

### Describe the solution you'd like

 I suggest option `sourceMapType` or a new value.
Why not? Just add `devtool: 'inline-source-map'` to the `webpack.config.js` if this option is set.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I don't want additional dependencies, plugins or hacks. Just an official option in the build CLI. Please üôè 
Btw. `ngx-build-plus` does not work. I don't want to rely on these 3rd party libs. Another risky build breaker.
It's really just a minor change in Angular CLI, or not?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Inline SourceMap Option" (#18975)

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>webpack-contrib/stylus-loader</summary>

### [`v4.1.0`](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#​410-httpsgithubcomwebpack-contribstylus-loadercomparev400v410-2020-10-02)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/compare/v4.0.0...v4.1.0)

##### Features

-   webpack resolver supports the `import` option ([8bca526](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/commit/8bca5262b5b3223108d14f8e10617ae6ca8dd85f))

##### Bug Fixes

-   source maps ([#​290](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/issues/290)) ([1be8169](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/commit/1be8169c888d1a8e3531e79ebe1e1ef53d7821e7))

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/compare/v3.0.2...v4.0.0)

-   minimum require `Node.js` version is `10.13`, minimum require `webpack` version is `4`

-   sourcemaps contain absolute `sources` by default

##### Features

-   added `additionalData` option ([#​248](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/issues/248)) ([9f781b7](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/commit/9f781b706ab971abdf99440ee1b5d8157206638f))
-   added `hoistAtrules` option ([#​276](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/issues/276)) ([90ff982](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/commit/90ff9822736943a2c03bdcd0d3a4740cd3811484))
-   added `lineNumbers` option ([#​278](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/issues/278)) ([637575c](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/commit/637575c7a7a8e6889df639fa4d0f0255649823dd))
-   added `webpackImporter` option ([#​244](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/issues/244)) ([bbe232a](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/commit/bbe232ad8d363f0d2cb7e55f85f10bd3cd8886e4))
-   allow to pass `stylusOptions` using function ([028a759](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/commit/028a7595e77b2532ee497df52ab8611de69dfd5f))
-   allow to define raw parameter ([b5c75ed](https://togithub.com/webpack-contrib/stylus-loader/commit/b5c75edab99494cb1d3dfad496e409c2930e8027))

##### Bug Fixes

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): add blank line in migration commit message
Issues.Body:
When using the `-C` option of `update`, the commit message of the migration is missing a blank line between the subject and body. 

For example,

Previously was missing blank line after the commit subject:
```
@angular/cli migration - rename-browserslist-config
Update Browserslist configuration file name to '.browserslistrc' from deprecated 'browserslist'.
```

Now fixed:
```
@angular/cli migration - rename-browserslist-config

Update Browserslist configuration file name to '.browserslistrc' from deprecated 'browserslist'.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular/cli): add blank line in migration commit message" (#18971)

Issues.Title: Curly brace positioned incorrectly in new angular.json file
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Perhaps, but not recent. ### Description When creating a new project, the very end of `angular.json` has 2 curly braces on the same line next to each other. The second one should be indented on the next line. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create a new project with `ng new`, scroll to the very bottom of the created `angular.json` file, and notice the 2 curly braces right above `defaultProject`. ## üåç Your Environment 
Angular CLI: 10.1.4
Node: 14.13.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular:
...

Issues.Title: help(Mat Datepicker): Do not autocomplete date when focus is out
Issues.Body:
#### What are you trying to do?

I've setup a datepicker and I want to type 1 and focus out the input and keep the 1. But instead the datepicker gets autocompleted with 1/1/2001. My client doesn't like that!!

`<mat-form-field appearance="fill">
  <mat-label>Choose a date</mat-label>
  <input matInput [matDatepicker]="picker">
  <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
  <mat-datepicker #picker></mat-datepicker>
</mat-form-field>`

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

Pressing tab or leaving the focus out of the input autocompletes the date and I dont want that

#### Reproduction

The issue is easily reproduced in the same page of Angular Material documentation in browsers like Chrome, Safari, IE11, etc
https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/overview


Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/overview
2.  Find a datepicker
3. Type 1
4. Press tab or focus the input out
5. See how date gets autocompleted with 1/1/2001
6. My expectation is if I type 1 then leave it as 1. We take care of validations.
  
#### Environment

All browsers, All devices, All OS.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "help(Mat Datepicker): Do not autocomplete date when focus is out" (#20741)

Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

A user should be able to set an own icon for e.g. the indeterminate state. It would be nice if you can set a SVG file in CSS or register your icon in the matIconRegistry and then give the user the functionality to set the icon for the states after that.

#### Use Case

Issues.Title: Scrollblock for Dialogs and Bottom Sheets: Always add 'cdk-global-scrollblock' class to the root when opening a bottom sheet or dialog
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

When opening a dialog/bottom sheet the 'cdk-global-scrollblock' is applied to the html tag, preventing the background to be scrollable through the modal. According to the answer of @crisbeto "The dialog won't try to block scrolling if the page isn't scrollable" - https://github.com/angular/components/issues/16864

But actually I have a use case (with bottom sheets), where it would be useful to always apply the class.

#### Use Case

I have a bottom sheet menu, from which I can open other bottom sheets. The first (menu) bottom sheet applies 'cdk-global-scrollblock'. When the other one is opened, the background is not scrollable anymore (because of the blocking class), so it removes it again, making the page in the background scrollable again.

My use case is only with bottom sheets, but since the similar issue, https://github.com/angular/components/issues/16864, describes the same problem, I assume dialogs and bottom sheets work the same in this behaviour. Correct me, if I am wrong.

#### Feature Request (Summary)

If 'cdk-global-scrollblock' is applied and a new bottom sheet/dialog is opened, the class should stay.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Scrollblock for Dialogs and Bottom Sheets: Always add 'cdk-global-scrollblock' class to the root when opening a bottom sheet or dialog" (#20734)

Issues.Title: feat(MatDatepickerModule): Inclusive End Date on date range selection
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Currently when using the new date range picker component, the end date is exlucded from the date selection. It would be helpful to have an option to set the date picker to be inclusive of the end day.

#### Use Case

A user is looking for something on a single specific day, so they may set the start and end dates in the range to the same value, expecting that the range would be set for that day only.

Currently if you select the same start and end date in your range, it's essentially a range of 0 seconds. The component allows this, but it doesnt really make sense.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(MatDatepickerModule): Inclusive End Date on date range selection" (#20736)

Issues.Title: bug(MatCheckbox/MatSlideToggle/DragDrop): Components not functioning in mobile under upgraded angularjs material to angular material project
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

I've created a stackblitz for this: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-qhprlc
You can view the issue in mobile: https://angular-ivy-qhprlc.stackblitz.io/

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create an angularjs to angular upgrade project which includes both angularjs material and angular material.
2. Add a MatCheckbox, MaxSlideToggle, or DragDrop list.
 
#### Expected Behavior

I expect the checkbox to check when tapped.

I expect the slidetoggle to toggle when tapped.

I expect to be able to sort the list when taping and dragging on an item.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

MatCheckbox will display the ripple effect, but not become checked when tapped.

MatSlideToggle also displays the ripple effect, but does not toggle when tapped.

The dragdrop list will pick up the item and move it when tapped and drag. Releasing the tap does not drop the time. Tapping again in the list will move the item originally selected to the new place tapped. Tapping outside of the list will drop the item where it was released.

Note this a further investigation of issues #19466 and #17146, which I've finally been able to get a repo on stackblitz for.
https://github.com/angular/components/issues/19466
https://github.com/angular/components/issues/17146

#### Environment

- Angular: 7.2.8, 8.2.7, 9.1.0, 10.1.4
- CDK/Material: 7.2, 8.2, 9.2, 10.2.3
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, Android
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(MatCheckbox/MatSlideToggle/DragDrop): Components not functioning in mobile under upgraded angularjs material to angular material project" (#20724)

Issues.Title: fix(material/slider): some screen readers announcing long decimal values
Issues.Body:
It looks like some screen readers announce the value of a slider by calculating the percentage themselves using the `aria-valuemin`, `aria-valuemax` and `aria-valuenow`. The problem is that they don't round down the decimals so for a slider between 0 and 1 with a step of 0.1, they end up reading out values like 0.20000068. These changes work around the issue by setting `aria-valuetext` to the same value that we shown in the thumb which we truncate ourselves.

Fixes #20719.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/slider): some screen readers announcing long decimal values" (#20721)

Issues.Title: bug(cdk-table): Row differ (trackBy) does not detect row template changes
Issues.Body:
The CDK Table will detect changes in rows based on a differ which is based on the `trackBy` input function.

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/4152aec5d421d993246b1ede3803027082330492/src/cdk/table/table.ts#L517-L519

This is fine when actual data changes but it does not handle a scenario where the row template has changed but the data has not changed, which is an issue especially when working with virtual scroll.

Since the trackBy handler does not get access to the `rowDef`, only to the index and raw row data, it is not possible to workaround.
 > Even if there is access to the rowDef, trackBy is not a predicate so it will be hard to return something logical there, trackBy is for identity, this one needs to happen outside of the trackBy

In some cases, one might write an alternate `trackBy` function but it will not do for all scenarios. Moreover, the `trackBy` function must be dead simple and fast, if the view port is large, showing enough rows with enough columns it becomes a bottleneck.

Usually, most performant way to do the trackBy is just return the index.

However, if the rowDef has changed, it will not be possible to detect it.

Once diff has been calculated, the call to `renderRows` will ignore the change in the row template definition

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/4152aec5d421d993246b1ede3803027082330492/src/cdk/table/table.ts#L611-L623

It will not call `_renderCellTemplateForItem` leaving it with the old template cached in the table.


#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-qvzms7?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftable-flex-basic-example.ts

Basically, we need to have multiple row definitions (CdkRowDef) but `multiTemplateDataRows` is set to false.
We define 2 row templates with `when` predicates, where the 2 predicates are opposite, if one is on the other is off and vice versa.

Using a simple button to toggle a boolean flag we switch between the 2 predicates.

If we use a simple button it will not work, we switch the flag but it does not change the rendered template for the row.

Using the `ChangeDetectorRef` to run manual CD will not work as well because the table handles it's own diff mechanism when it comes to row diffing.

The only way (I found so far...) to force the proper row template to render is calling `_forceRenderDataRows();`  which is private. The will force render the entire dataset, using the new row template. This is bad of course, as it's using a private method and it will force render ALL rows, while in real scenarios one will only want some to re-render.
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
Being able to change the row definition template and have the CDK Table autodetect and render it.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
CDK Table fail to detect changes in the row definition template.

#### Environment

- Angular: 10+
- CDK/Material: 10+
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(cdk-table): Row differ (trackBy) does not detect row template changes" (#20717)

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/testing): add the ability to dispatch arbitrary events
Issues.Body:
Allows for arbitrary events to be dispatched through a `TestElement`. This covers the following use cases:
1. Some events can't be simulated easily without a user interaction (e.g. `change` event on an `input`).
2. Allows for custom DOM event handlers to be triggered.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk/testing): add the ability to dispatch arbitrary events" (#20714)

Issues.Title: fix(material/datepicker): don't handle escape key presses with modifier
Issues.Body: Aligns the datepicker's escape key handling with the rest of the components where they aren't being handled if the user is pressing a modifier key.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/datepicker): don't handle escape key presses with modifier" (#20713)
